member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.HorizonFromVector(CosineKitty.AstroVector,CosineKitty.Refraction)
member.summary: Converts Cartesian coordinates to horizontal coordinates.
member.remarks:
Given a horizontal Cartesian vector, returns horizontal azimuth and altitude.
*IMPORTANT:* This function differs from #Astronomy.SphereFromVector in two ways: - `Astronomy.SphereFromVector` returns a `lon` value that represents azimuth defined counterclockwise from north (e.g., west = +90), but this function represents a clockwise rotation (e.g., east = +90). The difference is because `Astronomy.SphereFromVector` is intended to preserve the vector "right-hand rule", while this function defines azimuth in a more traditional way as used in navigation and cartography. - This function optionally corrects for atmospheric refraction, while `Astronomy.SphereFromVector` does not.
The returned structure contains the azimuth in `lon`. It is measured in degrees clockwise from north: east = +90 degrees, west = +270 degrees.
The altitude is stored in `lat`.
The distance to the observed object is stored in `dist`, and is expressed in astronomical units (AU).
member.param: Cartesian vector to be converted to horizontal coordinates.

`Refraction.Normal`: correct altitude for atmospheric refraction (recommended). `Refraction.None`: no atmospheric refraction correction is performed. `Refraction.JplHor`: for JPL Horizons compatibility testing only; not recommended for normal use.
member.returns: Horizontal spherical coordinates as described above.

member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.VectorFromHorizon(CosineKitty.Spherical,CosineKitty.AstroTime,CosineKitty.Refraction)
member.summary: Given apparent angular horizontal coordinates in `sphere`, calculate horizontal vector.
member.param: A structure that contains apparent horizontal coordinates: `lat` holds the refracted altitude angle, `lon` holds the azimuth in degrees clockwise from north, and `dist` holds the distance from the observer to the object in AU.
The date and time of the observation. This is needed because the returned #AstroVector requires a valid time value when passed to certain other functions.
The refraction option used to model atmospheric lensing. See #Astronomy.RefractionAngle. This specifies how refraction is to be removed from the altitude stored in `sphere.lat`.
member.returns: A vector in the horizontal system: `x` = north, `y` = west, and `z` = zenith (up).

member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.RefractionAngle(CosineKitty.Refraction,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the amount of "lift" to an altitude angle caused by atmospheric refraction.
member.remarks: Given an altitude angle and a refraction option, calculates the amount of "lift" caused by atmospheric refraction. This is the number of degrees higher in the sky an object appears due to the lensing of the Earth's atmosphere. This function works best near sea level. To correct for higher elevations, call #Astronomy.Atmosphere for that elevation and multiply the refraction angle by the resulting relative density.
member.param: The option selecting which refraction correction to use. If `Refraction.Normal`, uses a well-behaved refraction model that works well for all valid values (-90 to +90) of `altitude`. If `Refraction.JplHor`, this function returns a compatible value with the JPL Horizons tool. If any other value (including `Refraction.None`), this function returns 0.
An altitude angle in a horizontal coordinate system. Must be a value between -90 and +90.
member.returns: The angular adjustment in degrees to be added to the altitude angle to correct for atmospheric lensing.

member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.InverseRefractionAngle(CosineKitty.Refraction,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of an atmospheric refraction angle.
member.remarks: Given an observed altitude angle that includes atmospheric refraction, calculates the negative angular correction to obtain the unrefracted altitude. This is useful for cases where observed horizontal coordinates are to be converted to another orientation system, but refraction first must be removed from the observed position.
member.param: The option selecting which refraction correction to use. See #Astronomy.RefractionAngle.
The apparent altitude that includes atmospheric refraction.
member.returns: The angular adjustment in degrees to be added to the altitude angle to correct for atmospheric lensing. This will be less than or equal to zero.

member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.RotationAxis(CosineKitty.Body,CosineKitty.AstroTime)
member.summary: Calculates information about a body's rotation axis at a given time.
member.remarks:
Calculates the orientation of a body's rotation axis, along with the rotation angle of its prime meridian, at a given moment in time.
This function uses formulas standardized by the IAU Working Group on Cartographics and Rotational Elements 2015 report, as described in the following document:
https://astropedia.astrogeology.usgs.gov/download/Docs/WGCCRE/WGCCRE2015reprint.pdf
See #AxisInfo for more detailed information.
member.param: One of the following values: `Body.Sun`, `Body.Moon`, `Body.Mercury`, `Body.Venus`, `Body.Earth`, `Body.Mars`, `Body.Jupiter`, `Body.Saturn`, `Body.Uranus`, `Body.Neptune`, `Body.Pluto`.
The time at which to calculate the body's rotation axis.
member.returns: North pole orientation and body spin angle.

member.returns: A rotation matrix that converts EQD at `time` to EQJ.

member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.Rotation_EQD_HOR(CosineKitty.AstroTime,CosineKitty.Observer)
member.summary: Calculates a rotation matrix from equatorial of-date (EQD) to horizontal (HOR).
member.remarks: This is one of the family of functions that returns a rotation matrix for converting from one orientation to another. Source: EQD = equatorial system, using equator of the specified date/time. Target: HOR = horizontal system.
member.param: The date and time at which the Earth's equator applies.
A location near the Earth's mean sea level that defines the observer's horizon.
member.returns: A rotation matrix that converts EQD to HOR at `time` and for `observer`. The components of the horizontal vector are: x = north, y = west, z = zenith (straight up from the observer). These components are chosen so that the "right-hand rule" works for the vector and so that north represents the direction where azimuth = 0.

member.name: M:CosineKitty.Astronomy.Constellation(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Determines the constellation that contains the given point in the sky.
member.remarks: Given J2000 equatorial (EQJ) coordinates of a point in the sky, determines the constellation that contains that point.
member.param: The right ascension (RA) of a point in the sky, using the J2000 equatorial system (EQJ).
The declination (DEC) of a point in the sky, using the J2000 equatorial system (EQJ).
member.returns: A structure that contains the 3-letter abbreviation and full name of the constellation that contains the given (ra,dec), along with the converted B1875 (ra,dec) for that point.
